awd_titl_txt: Guided by Evidence: Changing the disciplinary culture of teaching and learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Evidence is mounting that students who are actively engaged in constructing knowledge achieve deeper conceptual understanding and more durable learning. Gateway Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) courses that utilize active learning have higher pass rates, which could ultimately lead to greater persistence of students on STEM career trajectories. Thus, the wider adoption of these active learning approaches is key to maintaining our scientific research enterprise and cultivating a diverse, scientifically literate workforce.

This study will use the Characteristics of Dissemination Success (CODS) model as a theoretical framework for changing the culture of teaching and learning in the biological sciences at the University of Maryland. Through engagement in a faculty learning community, instructors within the first four courses in the biological sciences curriculum will (1) develop progressive learning activities that employ evidence-based teaching approaches, then implement these in a coordinated fashion; (2) gather evidence for the effectiveness of their use of these approaches via an iterative process of monitoring student learning, then using this feedback to refine instructional activities; and (3) implement strategies that help students recognize evidence of their learning, to gain student buy-in for approaches that require greater effort and engagement. The success of the CODS model in fostering broader changes to the culture of teaching will be evaluated using a combination of quantitative and qualitative approaches.

This project aims to shift the culture of STEM course redesign from a solitary endeavor to a communal (and therefore sustainable) effort. It will foster new opportunities for interaction between like-minded colleagues in different STEM departments, creating a cadre of faculty dedicated to education reform. The project will also help a very diverse UMD student population, many of whom will become STEM professionals or K-12 science teachers, to develop metacognitive skills that enhance learning.

por.por_cntn:
The Guided by Evidence project used the Characteristics of Dissemination Success (CODS) model as a theoretical framework for changing the culture of teaching and learning in the biological sciences at a large, public research extensive university. Through engagement in a faculty learning community, instructors within the first four courses in the biological sciences curriculum (1) developed progressive learning activities that employed evidence-based teaching approaches; (2) gathered evidence for the effectiveness of their use of these approaches via an iterative process of monitoring student learning, then used this feedback to refine instructional activities; and (3) implemented strategies to help students recognize evidence of their learning, with the ultimate goal of gaining student buy-in for approaches that require greater effort and engagement. Over the three-year term of the project, the faculty learning community held regular meetings and biannual, full-day teaching retreats. The project documented significant increases over time in faculty self-efficacy regarding teaching and their reported use of student-centered teaching approaches, particularly in faculty who initially were less confident and less likely to use student-centered approaches. 

Participating faculty collaborated to develop teaching modules on foundational topics and skills that spanned the introductory curriculum: Mendelian genetics, tree thinking (phylogenetics), quantitative reasoning, and making and interpreting graphs. The modules, known as Toolkits, can be incorporated into the biological sciences curriculum in multiple ways. They can serve as an introduction to new topics in introductory biology, help new transfer students identify and address possible gaps in their background knowledge, and allow students in more advanced courses to refresh their understanding. Toolkits consist of a quiz that diagnoses gaps in student understanding, supplementary content (readings and videos), and practice quizzes (with questions drawn from a large question bank). A pilot study of how students used the Toolkits indicated that after they took the diagnostic quiz, a large majority followed up by exploring the supplementary content, taking practice quizzes, and retaking the diagnostic quiz to solidify their understanding. Student feedback on the format and content of the Toolkits was enthusiastically positive. 

Another aspect of the project explored whether there were systematic differences in student attitudes that have implications for greater adoption of active learning in introductory biology courses. Hierarchical clustering revealed five distinct clusters of students that differed in attitudes towards learning biology, use of quantitative approaches in biology, and use of student-centered, active teaching methods. These clusters were also different in the distribution of student majors, the students' likelihood of having taken a previous biology course, and their preprofessional aspirations. Understanding student attitudes and the origins of those attitudes is a critical step in cultivating student receptivity to novel instructional methods and can help instructors to create a more positive learning environment for all students.

The CODS framework was an effective way of conceptualizing the complex relationships that govern instructional practices and need to be taken into account when promoting institutional change. It provided us with a way to identify potential levers for catalyzing change and metrics that could be used to document long term shifts in the culture of teaching. An important outcome of the project has been the enduring collaborative relationships between participating faculty, who have subsequently taken leadership roles in new departmental and campus efforts to make teaching more effective and inclusive.
